questions.question: Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for a patient with acute decompensated heart failure?
questions.explanation: The initial management of acute decompensated heart failure focuses on symptom relief with diuresis (IV furosemide) and oxygen therapy to improve oxygenation. More invasive interventions are reserved for specific cases.

questions.question: A 65-year-old male presents with sudden-onset aphasia and right-sided weakness. CT head shows no hemorrhage. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.explanation: For ischemic stroke presenting within 4.5 hours of symptom onset with no contraindications, IV tPA is the standard of care. Time is critical for neuronal salvage.

questions.question: Which diagnostic test is most specific for rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.explanation: Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies have higher specificity (about 95%) for rheumatoid arthritis compared to rheumatoid factor (about 85%).

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with polyuria, polydipsia, and weight loss. Random glucose is 320 mg/dL. Which test confirms type 1 diabetes?
questions.explanation: Islet cell antibodies are specific markers for autoimmune destruction of pancreatic beta cells, confirming type 1 diabetes. Other options diagnose diabetes but don't differentiate between types.

questions.question: Which antibiotic is contraindicated in a patient with myasthenia gravis?
questions.explanation: Macrolide antibiotics like azithromycin can exacerbate myasthenia gravis by interfering with neuromuscular transmission. Fluoroquinolones and aminoglycosides are also contraindicated.
